articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Playbook for DOGE Has a Precedent: X
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk is wielding his X account to single out federal employees and agencies for cuts. He has used this method before.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk is wielding his X account to single out federal employees and agencies for cuts. He has used this method before.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since President-elect Donald J. Trump last month named Elon Musk to help lead a new Department of Government Efficiency, the tech billionaire has turned to X to trumpet his plans.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger

articles.headline: Trump’s Treasury Pick Is Poised to Test ‘Three Arrows’ Economic Strategy
articles.snippet: Scott Bessent’s “3-3-3” plan to stimulate growth, reduce the deficit and expand oil production will soon face economic realities.
articles.abstract: Scott Bessent’s “3-3-3” plan to stimulate growth, reduce the deficit and expand oil production will soon face economic realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set out to rejuvenate Japan’s economy more than a decade ago, he laid out a strategy known as the “Three Arrows,” which aimed to banish deflation by easing monetary policy, increasing government spending and restructuring the economy so that it was poised for growth.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Rebecca F. Elliott

articles.headline: McKinsey to Pay $650 Million in Opioid Settlement With Justice Department
articles.snippet: A former senior partner will also plead guilty to obstruction of justice after destroying company documents.
articles.abstract: A former senior partner will also plead guilty to obstruction of justice after destroying company documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: McKinsey & Company has agreed to pay $650 million to settle a Justice Department investigation of its work with the opioid maker Purdue Pharma. A former senior partner has also agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice for destroying internal company records in connection with that work.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: In Port Labor Dispute, Trump Backed a Union That Courted Him
articles.snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump is supporting the International Longshoremen’s Association, which could strike soon if it doesn’t reach a deal on automation with employers.
articles.abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is supporting the International Longshoremen’s Association, which could strike soon if it doesn’t reach a deal on automation with employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leaders of some labor unions tried to establish good relations with Donald J. Trump before the election — and for one of them, that effort may already be paying off.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis

articles.headline: In Display of Fealty, Tech Industry Curries Favor With Trump
articles.snippet: It was a week of frenzied activity, as Silicon Valley billionaires and their companies brandished checks and compliments for the President-elect.
articles.abstract: It was a week of frenzied activity, as Silicon Valley billionaires and their companies brandished checks and compliments for the President-elect.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $1 million donations came gradually — and then all at once.
articles.byline: By Theodore Schleifer and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Syria Shudders as Assad’s Prison Atrocities Come Into the Light
articles.snippet: At the country’s most notorious prison, Syrians confront their worst fears: that they will never know what happened to the loved ones who disappeared.
articles.abstract: At the country’s most notorious prison, Syrians confront their worst fears: that they will never know what happened to the loved ones who disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: People came by the thousands the day after the rebels arrived in Damascus, racing down the once desolate stretch of road, up a jagged footpath cut into the limestone hillside and through the towering metal gates of Syria’s most notorious prison. They flooded the halls lined with cells, searching for loved ones who had disappeared into the black hole of torture prisons under Bashar al-Assad’s government.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: South Korea’s President Is Impeached After Martial Law Crisis
articles.snippet: Some members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. But the political uncertainty is far from over.
articles.abstract: Some members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. But the political uncertainty is far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eleven days ago, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea made a bold power grab, putting the country under military rule for the first time in 45 years, citing frustration at the opposition for obstructing his agenda in Parliament.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun, Jin Yu Young and Victoria Kim

articles.headline: ABC to Pay $15 Million to Settle a Defamation Suit Brought by Trump
articles.snippet: The outcome of the lawsuit marks an unusual victory for President-elect Donald J. Trump in his ongoing legal campaign against national news organizations.
articles.abstract: The outcome of the lawsuit marks an unusual victory for President-elect Donald J. Trump in his ongoing legal campaign against national news organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABC News is set to pay $15 million to settle a defamation lawsuit brought by Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Security Strategy of Recruiting Cheap Militiamen Backfires in Africa
articles.snippet: By arming civilians who are poorly trained and have little to no respect for human rights, the military in Burkina Faso has brought the West African nation to the brink of civil war.
articles.abstract: By arming civilians who are poorly trained and have little to no respect for human rights, the military in Burkina Faso has brought the West African nation to the brink of civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were falling asleep on a thin mat that they had been sharing since they were married five years ago. Suddenly, the roar of motorcycles woke them up. Armed men then dragged Rainatou Diallo and her husband, Adama Diallo, out of bed and into their courtyard.
articles.byline: By Elian Peltier and Arlette Bashizi

articles.headline: ‘They Had the Desire to Return’
articles.snippet: Elated residents are trickling home to their shattered Syrian town, a rebel stronghold controlled until recently by the government.
articles.abstract: Elated residents are trickling home to their shattered Syrian town, a rebel stronghold controlled until recently by the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The skies were quiet the other night in the northwestern town of Tel Rifaat, Syria, and relief was palpable among fighters and civilians who have lived for years under the constant threat of bombardment.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and David Guttenfelder

articles.headline: An Epidemic of Vicious School Brawls, Fueled by Student Cellphones
articles.snippet: Cafeteria melees. Students kicked in the head. Injured educators. Technology is stoking cycles of violence in schools across the United States.
articles.abstract: Cafeteria melees. Students kicked in the head. Injured educators. Technology is stoking cycles of violence in schools across the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ricardo Martinez, an 11th grader, was in his high school lunchroom in April when a mass brawl erupted.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer

articles.headline: The Alienation of Jaime Cachua
articles.snippet: His friends and family members in Rome, Ga., voted to support mass deportation. Now he’s scrambling to stay in the country.
articles.abstract: His friends and family members in Rome, Ga., voted to support mass deportation. Now he’s scrambling to stay in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: His wife was spiraling into insomnia, and his children were afraid to go to school, so Jaime Cachua sought out the person he trusted most in a crisis. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Georgia across from his father-in-law, Sky Atkins, the family patriarch. Jaime, 33, hadn’t seen his own father since he was 10 months old, when he left Mexico in a car seat bound for the United States. It was Sky, 45, who had stood by Jaime at his wedding, helped him move into his first house and stayed at the hospital overnight when one of Jaime’s children was sick with pneumonia.
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: How Will the Rebels Rule Syria? Their Past Offers Clues.
articles.snippet: The Islamist rebels who ousted Syria’s dictator ran a pragmatic and disciplined administration in the territory they controlled. They also jailed their critics.
articles.abstract: The Islamist rebels who ousted Syria’s dictator ran a pragmatic and disciplined administration in the territory they controlled. They also jailed their critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every fall, when farmers across the rolling, red dirt hills of Idlib Province in northern Syria harvest their olive crops, they routinely find at least one representative of the local tax authority stationed at any oil press.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Justin Scheck

articles.headline: Trump and His Picks Threaten More Lawsuits Over Critical Coverage
articles.snippet: The small flurry of threatened defamation suits is the latest sign that the incoming Trump administration appears poised to do what it can to crack down on unfavorable media coverage.
articles.abstract: The small flurry of threatened defamation suits is the latest sign that the incoming Trump administration appears poised to do what it can to crack down on unfavorable media coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The legal threats have arrived in various forms. One aired on CNN. Another came over the phone. More arrived in letters or emails.
articles.byline: By David Enrich

articles.headline: Seeking Relief From Brain Injury, Some Veterans Turn to Psychedelics
articles.snippet: Unable to find effective treatments at home, veterans with brain-injury symptoms are going abroad for psychedelics like ibogaine that are illegal in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Unable to find effective treatments at home, veterans with brain-injury symptoms are going abroad for psychedelics like ibogaine that are illegal in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: A van full of U.S. Special Operations veterans crossed the border into Mexico on a sunny day in July to execute a mission that, even to them, sounded pretty far out.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Mark Abramson

articles.headline: A Ride-Hailing Start-Up in Washington Tries to ‘Out-Uber Uber’
articles.snippet: A company called Empower is trying to take on Uber, Lyft and local regulators as it piles up fines and draws new passengers to its service.
articles.abstract: A company called Empower is trying to take on Uber, Lyft and local regulators as it piles up fines and draws new passengers to its service.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday morning outside Union Station’s train hall in Washington, a stream of taxicabs, Ubers and Lyfts pulled to the curb to pick up passengers.
articles.byline: By Eli Tan

articles.headline: Powell’s Fed Appears Headed for Another Collision With Trump
articles.snippet: Rates may not come down as much or as quickly as had been expected, just as Trump — a self-declared “low-rate guy” — returns to the White House.
articles.abstract: Rates may not come down as much or as quickly as had been expected, just as Trump — a self-declared “low-rate guy” — returns to the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the halls of the Federal Reserve’s headquarters overlooking Constitution Avenue in Washington, casual mentions of the incoming Trump administration are cautious and infrequent. That’s by design.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Why America’s Kurdish Allies Are Under Threat in a New Syria
articles.snippet: The Kurds helped the United States contain the Islamic State. Now they fear a resurgent Turkey that has long considered them an adversary. Here’s a guide.
articles.abstract: The Kurds helped the United States contain the Islamic State. Now they fear a resurgent Turkey that has long considered them an adversary. Here’s a guide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 13-year civil war between Syria’s government and rebel fighters has ended. But the peril is not over for Syria’s Kurdish minority.
articles.byline: By Lara Jakes

articles.headline: Amazon Disregarded Internal Warnings on Injuries, Senate Investigation Claims
articles.snippet: A staff report by the Senate labor committee, led by Bernie Sanders, uncovered evidence of internal concern about high injury rates at the e-commerce giant.
articles.abstract: A staff report by the Senate labor committee, led by Bernie Sanders, uncovered evidence of internal concern about high injury rates at the e-commerce giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, worker advocates and some government officials have argued that Amazon’s strict production quotas lead to high rates of injury for its warehouse employees. And for years, Amazon has rejected the criticism, arguing that it doesn’t use strict quotas, and that its injury rates are falling close to or below the industry average.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: German Government Collapses at a Perilous Time for Europe
articles.snippet: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote, deepening the political turbulence in one of the continent’s most powerful economies.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote, deepening the political turbulence in one of the continent’s most powerful economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The German government collapsed on Monday as Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote in Parliament, deepening a crisis of leadership across Europe at a time of mounting economic and security challenges.
articles.byline: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
